textRun.content: Aclate:Product - Speed up UI Load Time
What is the business value that the milestone will deliver

Currently Product UI load time is drastically slow (>30 secs to load) due to requesting large data sets (1M+ records) from the server. After the Milestone is implemented, REST API endpoints are extended to support pagination, while retaining backwards compatible behavior of loading the entire data set by default. UIs with performance problems (
) are modified to take advantage of pagination and limit the initially loaded data set.
Thrift Framework - Possibilities for adding pagination
JIRA issue is provided for the delivered implementation of this milestone.
JIRA issue provides a link to this P1 specification (in source code or published format).
the delivered artifacts, i.e. stages, deployments, CI runs, documents, builds, source code, etc.
JIRA issue provides a link to a recorded demo session proving acceptance criteria.
Stakeholder (i.e. P1 author) gives approval of fulfillment based on the
List the milestones on which this specification depends on.
Add backwards compatible pagination support to REST API GET calls
P1 ITD 1.1 - Use keyset approach for pagination
Which pagination strategy do we use?

Offset/limit pagination strategy is prone to data records being inserted/deleted, shifting the position of all of the items in the dataset, subsequent to the ones inserted/deleted. As Dimension Data is updated frequently and automatically as the new data is ingested, keyset pagination is approach is better suited, since its more resilient to data updates. It also opens up better possibilities for caching the distinct pages more easily.
P1 ITD 1.2 - Enhance the REST API endpoints with filtering and sorting capabilities in addition to paging

Different pages use the data obtained via REST API in a different way, performing filtering/processing on client before presenting the data to the user. How do we address this approach when moving to paged data fetch?
Leave the behavior as is. A subset of server-returned items will be presented to the user based on client-side filtering/processing behavior.
Enhance the REST API endpoints with filtering and sorting capabilities in addition to paging

While leaving the current behavior as is is the least costly option and it still delivers the result, it will result in more API calls (and thus additional server load), performance depending on circumstance (the data can be retrieved in 1 call or 10 calls, depending on how many entities are filtered out by client) and inconsistent experience for the user (100 or 1 item added on scrolling). Enhancing REST API with filtering and sorting capabilities will minimize the overall bandwidth between client and server, remove behavioral inconsistency and make the client thinner.
P1 ITD 1.3 - Introduce a configurable delay between user input event and issuing the data request

In previous implementation searching/filtering was done at the client side as all the data was present on client at the time of display. Therefore the resource cost of user rapidly modifying the search string and triggering multiple result filtering events though this was not excessively high. As this will no longer be the case, how do we deal with the situation?
Leave the current behavior as is
Introduce a configurable delay between user input event and issuing the data request.
Refresh the delay if other input events were registered throughout the delay timespan.

Leaving the behavior as is would cause an excessive amount of useless requests, which become obsolete immediately as new input is received. As current UI is designed to update the list immediately on input change, this will cause relatively heavy requests issued for every character of the search string, as long as incorrect behavior related to sequence of response arrival. Introducing a delay between user input events and issuing the data request significantly reduces the number of requests and probability of error, while not damaging the UX in a significant way. Use the default delay value of 500ms.
P1 ITD 1.4 - Initiate loading new data page when user is 20% of page size away from the bottom of the list
What should serve as a trigger to start loading the new data page?
Initiate loading new data page when user reaches the bottom of the list
Initiate loading new data page when user is 20% of page size away from the bottom of the list

Initiating new page data load when the user scrolls to the very bottom of the list will cause an excessive delay and thus a deterrence to the user experience. Pre-loading the new data page before the user reaches the bottom of the list will benefit to a more seamless user experience when scrolling.
P1 ITD 1.5 - Preload initial data page asynchronously on page load
At what point do we load the initial data page?
Load initial data page on demand
Preload initial data page synchronously on page load
Preload initial data page asynchronously on page load

While having the menu content displayed with no delay on first access is beneficial for UX purposes, doing this synchronously would introduce an unnecessary delay for the user, as he may utilize this time for different interactions with the page. Preloading the data page asynchronously reaps the fruits of not blocking the user from operating the page, while still improving the UX as data load operation begins earlier than requested by user explicitly and content is more readily available on demand.
Use pagination in front-end app to speed-up UI and decrease memory footprint.
These demos will be evaluated according to th
Backwards compatible pagination support added to REST API GET endpoints
environment with no changes in scope of this Milestone applied
environment with changes in scope of this Milestone applied
Above mentioned environments operate on identical data sets
Backwards compatible pagination support added to REST API GET endpoints, and functionality with most noticeable performance problems is adjusted to take advantage of pagination.
) have paging, filtering and sorting capabilities
When paging/filtering/sorting parameters are not supplied the endpoints behave identically on two environments /w and w/o changes applied
All of the endpoints in scope use keyset approach for pagination
Paging, filtering and sorting capabilities implemented are use case agnostic through the use of parameterization
Filtering and sorting involved are done by REST API using capabilities added in
Next data page load is initiated on scrolling, when the user is 20% of page size away from the bottom of the list
) pre-load the initial data page asynchronously on page load
On the web page load, data load request is issued, requesting the first page of data to be pre-fetched before the user interacts with the filter
The initial data load request is issued asynchronously and does not block the user from interacting with the UI

If the user attempts an action that would otherwise cause data request, before the initial data is loaded (e.g. opens the filter while the data is still being loaded), the data load request is not duplicated
For the UI search actions in scope (
), there is a delay between search user input events and data load initiation
The delay is configurable and is set to 500ms
Typing multiple characters within the delay timespan leads to only 1 request issued
Pressing a key within the delay timespan of the previous key press refreshes the delay before the data request is issued
) load within 500ms on a data set of 1M+ records
) is less on the environment with Milestone changes applied than on the environment without the changes applied
These demos will be evaluated according to th
The product will use less browser memory, and speed up UI
Access /menu endpoint (which was called to populate the Dimensions)
API call should show HTTP request with pagination
Show memory footprint and content download time
Scroll through /menu to access more items
More API calls to /menu endpoint should be seen with updated pagination parameters
Show memory footprint and content download time
Go to Product List of Executed Delete jobs
API call should show HTTP request with pagination
Show memory footprint and content download time
Scroll through time to find older jobs which were deleted
More API calls should be seen with updated pagination parameters
Show memory footprint and content download time

Currently, we have a single big /menu endpoint support variable parameters, return metrics or filter data. The endpoint doesnt support pagination. The frontend UI component doesnt support pagination too. Its a simple approach, but fits for most scenarios. The issue only happens when we have massive filters data.
The /menu endpoint is used/shared by many functional areas, the front UI component also require all data in one request, there are no redundant (or unused) data discovered.
If we can refactor /menus endpoint with pagination and search feature. Update UI component support pagination too, the frontend will be much more lightweight.
The APIs are implemented using the
. Although pagination isnt supported natively its possible to add, see e.g.
of keyset pagination.This is one option to avoid loading the entire data set into memory before filtering the specific page.
